hurrying to the crossing. 
Nesvftski rose, puffing, and went up to the general, smiling. 
"Would not your excellency like a little re- freshment?" he said. 
"It's a bad business," said the general with- out answering him, "our men have been wast- ing time." 
"Hadn't I better ride over, your excellency?" asked Nesvitski. 
"Yes, please do," answered the general, and he repeated the order that had already once been given in detail: "and tell the hussars that they are to cross last and to fire t
